body: SOME New Yorkers have been muttering that, with his fall from grace, Bernard B. Kerik is not worthy of having a jail bear his name. Sure he is. In case you missed this detail, the detention center in Lower Manhattan, commonly known as the Tombs, has been called the Bernard B. Kerik Complex since December 2001. Rudolph W. Giuliani, in his final days
title: NYC; Letting The Edifice Fit the Crime

body: IN 1979, when Patti Hagan moved to St. Mark's Avenue in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, there were scores of boarded-up buildings and nightly scenes of drug dealing and prostitution. Twenty-five years and countless renovations and community meetings later, about the biggest daily annoyance she faces are fliers slipped under her door announcing the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; In a War of Words, One Has the Power to Wound

body: A 69-year-old man died in a fire that broke out in his second-floor apartment in Prospect Heights yesterday, the Fire Department said. The fire was reported shortly before 4 p.m. in Apartment 2L at 760 Grand Avenue, a five-story building. The man was already in cardiac arrest when firefighters arrived and he was pronounced dead a short time later,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Fire Kills Man

Safe in the 718 area code, in Prospect Heights, Ms. Janowitz is

author: Mohammed Naseehu Ali is the author of ''The Prophet of Zongo Street,'' a story collection to be published next year.
body: HOW I came to possess the name of the boxer who was once the most famous and baddest man on the planet happened by accident. Well, not quite by accident. By religious default almost every male child born in the predominantly Islamic Zongo section of Kumasi, Ghana, where I grew up, had Mohammed as a first name. The Mohammed would be followed by a
title: THE NEXT WAVE; 'My Name Is Not Cool Anymore'

body: A fight that broke out on a subway platform in Brooklyn yesterday left two men and a teenager with stab wounds, police officials said. The incident briefly snarled train service during the evening commute. The fight, which involved at least five men, occurred shortly after 5:20 p.m. as passengers waited at the southbound platform for the Nos. 2 and
title: 2 Men and Teenager Stabbed in a Brooklyn Subway Station

body: IN the final year of the HBO hit series ''Sex and the City,'' the character Carrie Bradshaw and her Prada-touting friends experienced a number of firsts: Charlotte converted to Judaism and settled into a happy marriage with Harry; Samantha let a man into her heart; and Carrie finally saw the Eiffel Tower and, it appears, snagged Mr. Big -- maybe
title: 'Outer Borough' Finally Attracts The 'In' Crowd

body: IF Dr. Brown's Cel-Ray soda had a kick, it would taste exactly like the house aperitif at Franny's in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. ''I just love lovage,'' said Francine Stephens, Franny's owner, who
title: Mystery Herb, in Celery's Cloak

title: In District Lines, Critics See Albany Protecting Its Own

body: CROWN HEIGHTS is a study in contrasts. Thanks to a bountiful supply of often richly detailed single-family and multifamily homes, many of the community's streets are now lined with turn-of-the-20th-century town houses that have been painstakingly renovated. And as demand for housing in northwestern Brooklyn continues to push prices upward, a
title: LIVING IN/Crown Heights; Casting an Eye Toward Brooklyn's 'Hidden Jewel'

body: THERE are very few ways to outwit the market and find a bargain. title: The Benefits Of Living Above The Store

body: THE crucial decision this week is where to eat. Those who dare to set foot beyond the defensive perimeter of the convention site will find a city beckoning with more wonderful food of more varied types than just about anywhere else on earth. Let's start with a few New York staples, like the best pastrami sandwich. My favorite comes from Katz's
title: NEW YORK 2004: NEW YORK/DINING OUT; Beyond the Garden, Culinary Delights

body: With sunshine peeking through the clouds onto a crowded street festival at a Baptist church in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, Roger L. Green worked the crowd in typical campaign mode. He shook hands, slapped backs and spoke with nearly everyone along the way. But none of the voters questioned him about an issue that would normally draw intense scrutiny
title: Clouds Aside, Legislators Carry On With Their Campaigns; Albany Veterans Say Constituents Shrug Off Accusations and Convictions

body: Gaije Kushner went inside one late April morning to refresh her cup of tea, confident that her two huskies were safely confined to her backyard. When she returned about two minutes later, she said, both dogs, Sita and Sasha, were gone. Ms. Kushner, 31, a dog walker, quickly realized that the dogs had jumped the fence, and she ran into the street
title: What Will People Pay to Find Their Lost Dogs? Just About Anything

body: When catastrophic events unfold halfway around the globe, it seems there is always a phone-card-buying, satellite-TV-watching immigrant community in New York that is keeping a close, anxious and passionate eye on its homeland. title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Sudanese Immigrants See the Strife in Darfur, and Feel the Pain at Home

title: 11 Die in Spate of Homicides Reminiscent of Bloodier Days

title: $25 AND UNDER; A Taste of Haiti, Fiery and Fresh

title: The Brooklyn Nets

title: A Park Pretty for the Rich Yet Run-Down for the Poor; Prospect Park Overseers Direct Money To Make East Side More Like the West

body: Every Sunday, in more than 100 churches across New York City, pastors preach the Gospel in languages like Ibo, Twi and Ga. Conga drums drive songs of praise. Swaths of kente cloth cover bodies swaying in the pews. An explosion of African immigrant churches in the past 15 years has helped reshape religious worship in the city. The surge is creating
title: In New York, Gospel Resounds in African Tongues

title: Oohs and Ahs, Even From Those Who Didn't Get In

title: Use of Midwives, a Childbirth Phenomenon, Fades in City

title: CITY LORE; Put Down That Violin. Now.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; One Man's Solution To the Educational Rat Race

title: Nets Fans Demonstrate at Arena

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Ratner's Path To Buy Nets Had Pitfalls And Promise

body: Before the first N.B.A. tipoff at the gleaming arena that the developer Bruce C. Ratner envisions for the area straddling the Atlantic Avenue rail yards, Mr. Ratner will have to take on a scrappy squad from down the block: his neighbors. A more ethnically, economically and commercially diverse crew would be hard to assemble, even in New York City.
title: Guarding Their Homes Against the Bulldozer

body: Manhattan TRIBECA $600,000 176 Broadway (Maiden Lane) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,350-sq.-ft. duplex co-op in a prewar loft building; dining area, open kitchen, 11-ft. ceilings, hardwood floors; common roof garden, laundry facilities on every floor; maintenance $1,320, 64% tax-deductible; listed at $615,000, 11 weeks on market (broker: Tabak Real Estate)
title: Residential Sales

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement. MANHATTAN CHELSEA $835,000 463 West 21st Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. co-op in a prewar town house; dining area, renovated kitchen with upgraded appliances,
title: Residential Sales

body: A front-page article yesterday about reactions in Brooklyn to the possibility that the New Jersey Nets might relocate there misspelled the given name of a leader of the Prospect Heights Action Coalition, who was critical of the proposal to build an arena for the team. She is Patti Hagan, not Patty.
title: Corrections

body: The revival of Brooklyn has been painfully slow, an effort eked out neighborhood by neighborhood, with chic new restaurants in Fort Greene, artists' lofts in Williamsburg, new businesses in industrial Red Hook and the transformation of derelict factory buildings into million-dollar condominiums in an area with the unlikely name of Dumbo. But the
title: Yo, Dodgers? No Way! Brooklyn Is Betting on the Nets for Revival
